params.text:
SECTION 01

Ask an Interesting Question
Supervised Learning - Economics
Machine learning algorithms can indeed function as a magic box that can perform the task without any theoretical rules. Here we want to find out how ML can be used in the field of Economics
1.1 Reading: Predicting Stock prices using Machine learning

The ultimate question we wish to answer is: Can we predict stock prices using Supervised Machine Learning? 

This interactive notebook aims to provide step-by-step guides for Orange(no-code platform for building ML pipeline), to build an ML model that uses prices of one day to predict the stock price the next day. 

This notebook is based on the following article tutorial: Khan, A. H., Shah, A., Ali, A., Shahid, R., Zahid, Z. U., Sharif, M. U., Jan, T., & Zafar, M. H. (2023). A performance comparison of machine learning models for stock market prediction with novel investment strategy. PLOS ONE, 18(9)

SECTION 02

Get the Data

For this task, we need stock price data to train the model. In this task, we are using the stock prices data from yahoo finance website. The data provided along the exercise is the stock data from 2024-02-11 to 2024-02-18.

2.1.1 Instruction :

Select “CSV File Import” widget from “Data” tab and add it to the canvas.

2.1 Activity : Get the data

In this acitivity, we will load the provided dataset

2.1.2 Instructions:

make sure, you have downloaded the dataset file from moodle before proceeding further.

Double click on the File widget, this will open a new window and browse to the location of the dataset file and select the dataset.
2.2 Reading : Feature Engineering

We want to create an ML model to predict gain or loss for the next day, this information acts as output. However no such information exists, so we have to add such an attribute manually. For this, we create a 'signal' attribute in the existing dataset. The 'signal' is derived from the 'future_returns' attribute which stores percent changes in the closing price of a stock in two consecutive traded days. 'future_returns' is shifted by -1 to reflect that change in the next day is related to the current day and hence can be used to generate 'signal' attribute. In short, the 'signal' attribute of a day represents whether there is going to be a gain or a loss on the next day.

Similarly, for input we used 'Volume', 'Open-Close'(the difference between the Opening and closing price of a day), and 'Close-Low'(the difference between the closing and low price for a day)
2.3 MCQ : Feature Engineering

params.question: Which attribute in the dataset represents whether there is going to be a gain or a loss on the next day?

params.text:
2.3.1 Instructions :

Select “Formula” widget from “Transform” tab, add it to canvas and connect it to existing "CSV File Import" tab

2.3 Activity : creating necessary attributes

In this task, we 'future returns', 'Open-Close', and 'Close-Low' attribute to be used as input for training.

2.3.2 Instructions:

Open "Formula" icon and create 'Open-Close', 'Close-Low', and 'signal' attribute by pressing on "New" button. the final result can be seen in the figure

SECTION 03

Data Analysis
In this steps, we will analyse the coorelation between different input and output features and remove and coorelated features

3.1 Activity: visualize the data

view the modified data in previous step

3.1.1 Instruction: 

Drag 'Data table' icon from Data section and connect it to Formula to see how the data looks. It should look as shown in the figure.

3.2 Activity: select features for coorelation

We will select the input features and output features to see if any of them are coorelated to each other

3.2.1 Instruction: 

Drag 'Select Column' icon from Transform section and connect it to 'Data Table'. Open the 'Data Table' tab, Here we can ignore feature we are not using for input or output. Since we are using 'Datetime', 'Volume', 'Open-Close', 'Close-low' as input and 'signal' as output, we will ignore the rest features. we can simply drag the rest features to ignored section in the tab
3.3 Activity: View Coorelation

3.3.1 Instruction: 

Drag 'Correlation' icon from Unsupervised section and connect it to 'Select Column' icon. Open its tab to view coorelation between different features. Here we can see none of the features are strongly coorelated to each other.

SECTION 04

Splitting data and training the model
In this stage, we will split the data into train and test data. Train data will be used to train the model and test data will be used to validate the model.
2.2 Reading : Splitting data and training model

In this stage, we are splitting the data into training and testing datasets. The general rule of thumb is to use the 80-20 rule, i.e. 80% data as training and 20% for testing/validation.

Then we are training the ML model on the training dataset. For now, we are using the KNN method, however, it can easily be changed to other models.

4.2 Activity: select features for model

We will select the input features and output features to train the model

4.2.1 Instruction: 

Drag the 'Select Column' icon from the 'Transform' section and connect it to 'Data Table'. Open the 'Data Table' tab, Here we can ignore the feature we are not using for input or output. Since we are using 'Datetime', 'Volume', 'Open-Close', and 'Close-low' as input and 'signal' as output, we will ignore the rest features. we can simply drag the rest features to the ignored section in the tab. To use 'signal' as output, we will drag the 'signal' feature to the 'Target' section. The final result looks as in the figure
4.3 Reading : KNN

Among many supervised learning techniques, we will use one called "KNN", or "K-Nearest Neighbors", which is, in simple terms, a classification algorithm based on proximity.

Imagine you have a set of data points, each belonging to a specific class, and you need to determine the class of a new, unknown data point. KNN helps you do this by finding the "k" closest points in the training set to the new data point. The new point is then assigned to the class that is most common among its "k" nearest neighbors.

What makes KNN special is its simplicity and effectiveness, especially for small datasets or problems where the decision boundary is irregular. Unlike other algorithms, KNN doesn't explicitly build a model; instead, it makes decisions based on the entire training dataset, making it a non-parametric and lazy learning algorithm.
4.4 MCQ : KNN

choices.question: What factor does the K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) algorithm use to classify a new, unknown data point?
answers:
Proximity to the nearest data points

Probability estimates

Decision boundaries

Model parameters and weights

choices.question: In K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), what does the parameter 'k' represent?
answers:
The number of nearest neighbors to consider for classification

The number of features in the dataset

The number of decision boundaries

The maximum distance for classifying points

params.text:
4.4.1 Instructions :

We use 'preprocess' icon from 'Transform' section, and then connect it to select column. In the preprocess tab we can see different option to normalize, we wish to normalize between 0 and 1, as shown in the figure.

4.4 Activity: Normalize feature vectors

For better performance, it is a good idea to normalize the feature vectors

Instructions 01:

First we drag “Data Sampler” from 'Transform' section and connect it to existing 'preprocess' icon. In the 'Data Sampler' tab, there exists an option to give the ratio for train to test data. Here we select 80-20, as discussed.

4.5 Activity: splitting data

In this acitivity, we split the data into train and test data. The general rule of thumb is 80-20 i.e use 80% data to train and 20% data to validate.

4.6.1 Instruction :

First we will use the “kNN” widget from 'Model' section to train the model. It is connected to 'Data Sampler'. In the 'kNN' tab, there is options to change parameters as can be seen in the image.

4.6 Activity: training model

In this acitivity, we will create a kNN model to learn from the input data.

SECTION 05

Evaluation
In this task, we will evaluate the accuracy of the model.
5.1 Reading : Evaluation Metrics

Here are some metrics that Orange supports to evalute a model.

Accuracy: Of all the predictions we made, how many were correct?

Precision: Of all the positive predictions we made, how many were correct?

Recall: Of all the predictions that should have been positive, how many did we got correct?

f1-score: A score that combines precision and recall that is 1 for a perfect model and 0 for a terrible model.

MCC: Stands for Mathew's Correlation Coefficient, also called Phi coefficient. Another combined score that is also 1 for a perfect model and 0 for a terrible model.

5.2.1 Instruction :

First we will use the “prediction” widget from 'Evaluate' section to asses the accuracy of the model. In the tab, accuracy of the model is visible.

5.2 Activity: Evaluation

In this acitivity, we will evaluate the accuracy of the model
